prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IC 1623 band 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continuum observations with CO J=1-0 in one sideband.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
As a continuum proposal our correlator configuration is simply chosen to maximise the observing bandwidth.
The strong CO J=1-0 line (594 Jykm/s, Saito et al. 2015) will be mapped at a resolution of 2.59 km/s, which will nonetheless give velocity resolved data as the lines are up 110 km/s in width. We estimate a line sensitivity of ~1mJy with the proposed integration time.

The largest scale structure in any existing radio or ALMA map is ~15" (excluding slighter more extended tail-like structures seen in CO J=1-0 that can nonetheless be mapped due to their narrowness). The total extent of the region to be mapped is 25"x20". We select a resolution of 0.5" as a compromise between producing a map with enough independent beams to produce meaningful spatially resolved results and resolving out flux in the extended structure.
A single pointing is sufficient to cover this area in band 3.

The observational setup is entirely driven by the requirement to map the 100, 150, 230 and 345GHz continuum emission from the bright, compact starburst nucleus in IC 1623 (CO line data is of secondary interest here). We need data at the same resolution (and as similar uv-coverage as possible) in order to make flux ratio maps free from imaging artifacts. For images to be used to make ratio maps we consider 5-sigma as the lowest reliable flux. As the existing ALMA data have been made with a restoring beam of ~1" we base our sensitivity calculation on the assumption of the same restoring beam for simplicity, though higher resolution maps will be possible.
IC 1623 has been observed by ALMA in bands 3 & 7 in cycle 0 (fig. 1), Saito et al., 2015, Iono et al. 2013) and also by the SMA, including 214 and 340GHz continuum (Wilson et al. 2008). This makes estimating the required sensitivity and spatial distribution of emission easier, but there is clear evidence that structure exists on scales larger than those sampled by both the ALMA and SMA observations. We therefore refer also to radio observations between 8GHz (Condon et al. 1991, Clemens et al. 2008) and 22GHz (fig.1, Clemens et al. 2008) to make the best estimate of the spatial scales that need to be mapped, and sensitivities required. Estimates for band 4 are made by interpolation along the model fit shown in fig. 1 whereas estimates for band 6 are based on the ALMA band 7 image and integrated flux measured by Wilsonn et al. (2008) with the SMA.
The band 3 ALMA map shows structure consistent with both radio maps and band 7 emission down to a level of 0.1 mJy/beam. To map this to the 5-sigma level requires a sensitivity of 20 uJy/beam.
As a continuum proposal our correlator configuration is simply chosen to maximise the observing bandwidth.

The largest scale structure in any existing radio or ALMA map is ~15" (excluding slighter more extended tail-like structures seen in CO J=1-0 that can nonetheless be mapped due to their narrowness). The total extent of the region to be mapped is 25"x20". We select a resolution of 0.5" as a compromise between producing a map with enough independent beams to produce meaningful spatially resolved results and resolving out flux in the extended structure.
A single pointing is sufficient to cover this area in band 4.

The observational setup is entirely driven by the requirement to map the 100, 150, 230 and 345GHz continuum emission from the bright, compact starburst nucleus in IC 1623 (CO line data is of secondary interest here). We need data at the same resolution (and as similar uv-coverage as possible) in order to make flux ratio maps free from imaging artifacts. For images to be used to make ratio maps we consider 5-sigma as the lowest reliable flux. As the existing ALMA data have been made with a restoring beam of ~1" we base our sensitivity calculation on the assumption of the same restoring beam for simplicity, though higher resolution maps will be possible.
IC 1623 has been observed by ALMA in bands 3 & 7 in cycle 0 (fig. 1), Saito et al., 2015, Iono et al. 2013) and also by the SMA, including 214 and 340GHz continuum (Wilson et al. 2008). This makes estimating the required sensitivity and spatial distribution of emission easier, but there is clear evidence that structure exists on scales larger than those sampled by both the ALMA and SMA observations. We therefore refer also to radio observations between 8GHz (Condon et al. 1991, Clemens et al. 2008) and 22GHz (fig.1, Clemens et al. 2008) to make the best estimate of the spatial scales that need to be mapped, and sensitivities required. Estimates for band 4 are made by interpolation along the model fit shown in fig. 1 whereas estimates for band 6 are based on the ALMA band 7 image and integrated flux measured by Wilsonn et al. (2008) with the SMA.
For band 4 we assume that the spatial distribution of emission is the same as in band 3 and use our model fit to the entire SED to estimate the flux. This results in emission at the level of 0.15 mJy/beam at the same location as that in band 3. To map this to the 5-sigma level requires a sensitivity of 30 uJy/beam.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IC 1623 band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continuum observations with CO J=2-1 in one sideband.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
As a continuum proposal our correlator configuration is simply chosen to maximise the observing bandwidth.
The strong CO J=2-1 line (1109 Jykm/s, Wilson et al. 2008) will be mapped at a resolution of 1.3 km/s, which will nonetheless give velocity resolved data as the lines are up 110 km/s in width. We estimate a line sensitivity of ~2mJy with the proposed integration time.

The largest scale structure in any existing radio or ALMA map is ~15" (excluding slighter more extended tail-like structures seen in CO J=1-0 that can nonetheless be mapped due to their narrowness). The total extent of the region to be mapped is 25"x20". We select a resolution of 0.5" as a compromise between producing a map with enough independent beams to produce meaningful spatially resolved results and resolving out flux in the extended structure.
In band 6 a 3 point mosaic is required for both the 12m and 7m array.

The observational setup is entirely driven by the requirement to map the 100, 150, 230 and 345GHz continuum emission from the bright, compact starburst nucleus in IC 1623 (CO line data is of secondary interest here). We need data at the same resolution (and as similar uv-coverage as possible) in order to make flux ratio maps free from imaging artifacts. For images to be used to make ratio maps we consider 5-sigma as the lowest reliable flux. As the existing ALMA data have been made with a restoring beam of ~1" we base our sensitivity calculation on the assumption of the same restoring beam for simplicity, though higher resolution maps will be possible.
IC 1623 has been observed by ALMA in bands 3 & 7 in cycle 0 (fig. 1), Saito et al., 2015, Iono et al. 2013) and also by the SMA, including 214 and 340GHz continuum (Wilson et al. 2008). This makes estimating the required sensitivity and spatial distribution of emission easier, but there is clear evidence that structure exists on scales larger than those sampled by both the ALMA and SMA observations. We therefore refer also to radio observations between 8GHz (Condon et al. 1991, Clemens et al. 2008) and 22GHz (fig.1, Clemens et al. 2008) to make the best estimate of the spatial scales that need to be mapped, and sensitivities required. Estimates for band 4 are made by interpolation along the model fit shown in fig. 1 whereas estimates for band 6 are based on the ALMA band 7 image and integrated flux measured by Wilsonn et al. (2008) with the SMA.
The 1.4mm (214GHz, band 6) flux measured by Wilson et al. (2008) was 11 mJy. We therefore scale the band 7 ALMA map to this integrated flux and find the faintest structure to be 0.2 mJy/beam. To map this emission to the 5-sigma level requires a sensitivity of 40 uJy/beam.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IC 1623 band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continnum observation with CO 3-2 in one sideband.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
As a continuum proposal our correlator configuration is simply chosen to maximise the observing bandwidth.
The strong CO J=3-2 line (1530 Jykm/s, Wilson et al. 2008) will be mapped at a resolution of 0.86 km/s, which will nonetheless give velocity resolved data as the lines are up 110 km/s in width. We estimate a line sensitivity of ~14 mJy with the proposed integration time.

The largest scale structure in any existing radio or ALMA map is ~15" (excluding slighter more extended tail-like structures seen in CO J=1-0 that can nonetheless be mapped due to their narrowness). The total extent of the region to be mapped is 25"x20". We select a resolution of 0.5" as a compromise between producing a map with enough independent beams to produce meaningful spatially resolved results and resolving out flux in the extended structure.
In band 7 a 7 point mosaic is required for the 12m array, and a 3 point mosaic for the 7m array.

The observational setup is entirely driven by the requirement to map the 100, 150, 230 and 345GHz continuum emission from the bright, compact starburst nucleus in IC 1623 (CO line data is of secondary interest here). We need data at the same resolution (and as similar uv-coverage as possible) in order to make flux ratio maps free from imaging artifacts. For images to be used to make ratio maps we consider 5-sigma as the lowest reliable flux. As the existing ALMA data have been made with a restoring beam of ~1" we base our sensitivity calculation on the assumption of the same restoring beam for simplicity, though higher resolution maps will be possible.
IC 1623 has been observed by ALMA in bands 3 & 7 in cycle 0 (fig. 1), Saito et al., 2015, Iono et al. 2013) and also by the SMA, including 214 and 340GHz continuum (Wilson et al. 2008). This makes estimating the required sensitivity and spatial distribution of emission easier, but there is clear evidence that structure exists on scales larger than those sampled by both the ALMA and SMA observations. We therefore refer also to radio observations between 8GHz (Condon et al. 1991, Clemens et al. 2008) and 22GHz (fig.1, Clemens et al. 2008) to make the best estimate of the spatial scales that need to be mapped, and sensitivities required. Estimates for band 4 are made by interpolation along the model fit shown in fig. 1 whereas estimates for band 6 are based on the ALMA band 7 image and integrated flux measured by Wilsonn et al. (2008) with the SMA.
The band 7 ALMA map lacks short spacing flux (a visible negative bowl is seen around the source) so we use the integrated flux of 26 mJy measured by Wilson et al. 2008 and refer to the ALMA map for the spatial distribution. Scaling the ALMA map to the integrated SMA flux we find the faintest structure to be 0.4 mJy/beam. To map this emission to the 5-sigma level requires a sensitivity of 80 uJy/beam.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Is the star formation in a ULIRG just like that in a starburst galaxy but with a higher star formation rate? Does the star formation propagate out from the centre (or in some other direction) with time? There is evidence that the intense star formation in LIRGs and ULIRGs is actually not like that in less extreme objects. One such piece of evidence is an apparent deficit of free-free emission, making the radio spectra of these objects steeper than expected in the 20-100GHz range. This proposal explores this possibility by isolating the free-free emission for the first time.
We will map the 100, 145, 230 and 345 GHz continuum emission in the compact starburst nucleus of one of the closest LIRGs, IC 1623, and determine whether or not there is a deficit. As well as providing information about the evolution of a compact starburst nucleus, and how this relates to the state of the ISM, this study will also provide valuable information about the radio/mm spectrum in such objects, many of which will be detected at high redshift in future deep radio surveys.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00289.S, "Free-free and dust emission in the ULIRG IC 1623", Marcel Clemens 2012.1.00251.S, "Is star formation different in (U)LIRGs? Free-free, thermal dust and CO emission in IC 1623", Marcel Clemens
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, Cambridge, University of
Optica y Electronica , Instituto Nacional de Astrofisica
